If the characters answered Yahru's questions angrily or arrogantly, they are taken to {@creature Ras Nsi|ToA}. If they reacted in a calm, civil manner, they are brought to {@creature Fenthaza|ToA}.

entries.name: Audience with Ras Nsi
entries: {@creature Ras Nsi|ToA} meets with prisoners in the throne room ({@area area 11|2da|x}). He wants to know why the characters invaded Omu. If he finds their answer unsatisfactory, he views them as dangerous and has them put to death immediately. If {@creature Ras Nsi|ToA} learns that they've come to put an end to the death curse, he is intrigued. If they reveal that the cause lies in the Tomb of the Nine Gods, he releases them, gives them any remaining puzzle cubes they need to enter the tomb, and grants them safe passage out of Omu if they succeed in destroying the Soulmonger. He won't help them further, since that could incite a yuan-ti revolt.

entries.name: Audience with Fenthaza
entries: {@creature Fenthaza|ToA} meets with prisoners in her quarters ({@area area 5|2ba|x}). She sees the characters as pawns in her plot to overthrow {@creature Ras Nsi|ToA}. To determine whether they can be trusted, she assigns them to work as slaves under Slavemaster Issar ({@area area 19|2f7|x}). Issar assigns each character a labor, determined by rolling percentile dice and consulting the Slave Labors table. (More than one character can be given the same task.) As they perform labors, characters see how the temple functions and might find ways to escape.

If the characters perform their labors without incident or complaint for 1 day, they are brought before {@creature Fenthaza|ToA} once more. She promises them their freedom if they agree to overthrow {@creature Ras Nsi|ToA}. She also allows them to keep any puzzle cubes in {@creature Ras Nsi|ToA}'s custody. If they agree, she gives them the armory passphrases (see {@area area 4|2b7|x}) and encourages them to carry out a slave uprising. She also offers to ritually transform human characters into yuan-ti purebloods so they can get closer to {@creature Ras Nsi|ToA} (see {@area area 9|2ca|x}). While the characters sow confusion, she assembles her guards and priests (see areas 6 and 7), ambushes {@creature Ras Nsi|ToA}, and attempts to kill him.

If the coup is thwarted, {@creature Fenthaza|ToA} and her confederates are put to death. If the coup succeeds, {@creature Fenthaza|ToA} concludes that the characters have outlived their usefulness and tries to eliminate them. If the characters flee before she can betray them, {@creature Fenthaza|ToA} sends her air elemental (see {@area area 5|2ba|x}) to hunt them down and kill them.

rows: Muck out the dinosaur pen in {@area area 2|2b1|x}.
The character learns that Nahth ({@area area 1|2ad|x}) is susceptible to bribery.
Help Azi Mas rearrange the contents of the storeroom ({@area area 13|2e7|x}).
Azi Mas shares his suspicions that {@creature Fenthaza|ToA} is planning a coup.
Assist Xopal in the poison distillery ({@area area 14|2eb|x}).
Xopal sends the character, unescorted, to gather fungi from {@area area 22|301|x}.
Scrub the yuan-ti bathing in {@area area 16|2f1|x}.
The character learns that {@creature Fenthaza|ToA} had a prophetic dream about the Black Opal Crown, a treasure which the yuan-ti believe has the power to usher forth Dendar the Night Serpent.
Clean the yuan-ti nests in {@area area 18|2f5|x}.
The character overhears one yuan-ti whisper to another, in Common, "White feather, black mask." See {@area area 4|2b7|x} for the significance of these words.
Feed a dead prisoner to the hydra in {@area area 21|2ff|x}.
The characters find a folded-up piece of parchment hidden on the dead prisoner. On one side, it bears a crude map of the temple.
Nahth ({@creature Yuan-ti Malison (Type 1)||type 1 yuan-ti malison}), 4 {@creature Yuan-ti Broodguard|VGM|yuan-ti broodguards}, 3 {@creature Swarm of Poisonous Snakes||swarms of poisonous snakes}
The yuan-ti remain here, pulling reinforcements from {@area area 2|2b1|x}. The swarms are confined to the pits.
Soakosh ({@creature yuan-ti pureblood}), 4 {@creature Yuan-ti Broodguard|VGM|yuan-ti broodguards}, 2 {@creature Basilisk||basilisks}, 1 {@creature triceratops}

If combat erupts, one broodguard tries to strike the gong in {@area area 9|2ca|x}, placing the entire temple on alert. If the gong is struck by someone else, all the yuan-ti and basilisks leave to investigate. The triceratops stampedes toward {@area area 1|2ad|x} if attacked or threatened with fire.
1 {@creature Bone Naga (Spirit)||bone naga}, 2 {@creature Minotaur Skeleton||minotaur skeletons}
{@creature Fenthaza|ToA} ({@creature yuan-ti nightmare speaker|VGM}), 2 {@creature Yuan-ti Malison (Type 2)||yuan-ti malisons (type 2)}, 1 {@creature air elemental}
If threatened, the yuan-ti pull reinforcements from {@area area 6|2be|x}. The elemental remains in its urn until {@creature Fenthaza|ToA} releases it.
The yuan-ti broodguards remain here unless drawn to {@area area 5|2ba|x} by sounds of combat.
1 {@creature doppelganger}, 11 {@creature Yuan-ti Pureblood||yuan-ti purebloods}, 2 {@creature Yuan-ti Broodguard|VGM|yuan-ti broodguards}
The doppelganger helps characters working with the Red Wizards of Thay. The broodguards protect the purebloods.

{@creature Ras Nsi|ToA} (daytime only), {@creature Sekelok|ToA} ({@creature champion|VGM} variant), 2 {@creature Yuan-ti Malison (Type 1)||yuan-ti malisons (type 1)}, 3 {@creature Yuan-ti Broodguard|VGM|yuan-ti broodguards}, 4 {@creature Ghoul||ghouls}

{@creature Ras Nsi|ToA} retreats to {@area area 12|2e1|x} if threatened. If the gong in {@area area 9|2ca|x} is struck, {@creature Sekelok|ToA}, the malisons, and the broodguards investigate while the ghouls remain here.
{@creature Ras Nsi|ToA} (present only at night or when forced to flee from {@area area 11|2da|x})
{@creature Ras Nsi|ToA} flees or negotiates if outmatched.
The yuan-ti and zombies remain here.
The swarms are confined to the pit.
2 {@creature Yuan-ti Malison (Type 2)||yuan-ti malisons (type 2)}, 4 {@creature Yuan-ti Pureblood||yuan-ti purebloods}
If the gong in {@area area 9|2ca|x} is struck, the yuan-ti leave to investigate. If combat erupts here, reinforcements arrive from {@area area 17|2f3|x}.
Yahru ({@creature Yuan-ti Malison (Type 1)||type 1 yuan-ti malison}), 2 {@creature Gladiator||gladiators}
If the gong in {@area area 9|2ca|x} is struck, or if they detect a disturbance in {@area area 16|2f1|x}, the malison and the gladiators leave to investigate.
6 {@creature Yuan-ti Malison (Type 1)||yuan-ti malisons} (2 each of types 1, 2, and 3), 6 {@creature Yuan-ti Pureblood||yuan-ti purebloods}
If the gong in {@area area 9|2ca|x} is struck, the yuan-ti leave to investigate. Otherwise, they rest here.
Issar ({@creature Yuan-ti Malison (Type 3)||type 3yuan-ti malison}), 3 {@creature Yuan-ti Broodguard|VGM|yuan-ti broodguards}

The yuan-ti guard the secret entrance. If combat erupts, one of them flees to {@area area 19|2f7|x} to alert the yuan-ti there. Intruders caught trying to sneak past the guards are taken to {@area area 19|2f7|x} for questioning.
The hydra attacks swimmers as well as creatures that travel north of {@area area 18|2f5|x}. If a rowboat bell is rung, the hydra appears in {@dice 1d6} rounds and attacks unless it is properly fed.
{@dice 1d4} {@creature Yuan-ti Pureblood||yuan-ti purebloods} escorting a {@creature Yuan-ti Malison (Type 3)||type 3 yuan-ti malison}.
{@dice 1d4 + 1} {@creature Yuan-ti Pureblood||yuan-ti purebloods} escorting {@dice 2d4} captives (male and female Chultan human {@creature Commoner||commoners} of any alignment).
{@dice 2d4} {@creature Yuan-ti Pureblood||yuan-ti purebloods} returning to the temple from an expedition or patrol.
4 {@creature Yuan-ti Broodguard|VGM|yuan-ti broodguards} (see {@adventure appendix D|ToA|9}) carrying a {@creature Yuan-ti Malison (Type 2)||type 2 yuan-ti malison} on a litter.
1 {@creature Yuan-ti Malison (Type 1)||yuan-ti malison} returning to the temple. Roll a {@dice d6} to determine its type: 1–2, type 1; 3–4, type 2; 5–6, type 3.

1 {@creature yuan-ti abomination} arriving at the temple to challenge {@creature Ras Nsi|ToA}'s leadership. If {@creature Fenthaza|ToA} is alive, she uses her influence to arrange a showdown between {@creature Ras Nsi|ToA} and the abomination in the fane ({@area area 9|2ca|x}). If {@creature Fenthaza|ToA} is {@condition incapacitated} or dead, the abomination bullies its way to {@creature Ras Nsi|ToA}'s throne room ({@area area 11|2da|x}), where it is killed.

{@dice 2d4} insane {@creature Cult Fanatic||cult fanatics} (NE male and female humans of mixed ethnicities) seeking an audience with {@creature Ras Nsi|ToA}, to pledge their devotion to Dendar the Night Serpent. The cult fanatics bring tribute in the form of treasure (roll once on the Treasure Hoard: Challenge 0–4 table in {@book chapter 7|DMG|7|Random Treasure} of the {@i Dungeon Master's Guide}).

{@dice 2d6} {@creature Tribal Warrior||tribal warriors} (N male and female Chultan humans) delivering tribute to {@creature Ras Nsi|ToA}. This tribute consists of food, drink, and treasure (roll once on the Treasure Hoard: Challenge 0–4 table in {@book chapter 7|DMG|7|Random Treasure} of the {@i Dungeon Master's Guide}).

entries.name: Locations in the Temple
entries: Map 4.1 shows the layout of the entire temple. The following features are common throughout.

entries.name: Ceilings
entries: Unless otherwise noted, chamber ceilings are 20 feet high and corridor ceilings are 10 feet high.

entries.name: Doors
entries: Doors are made from worked stone, with 4-inch-wide holes spaced along their bottoms to allow Medium and smaller snakes to pass through. Doors are unlocked unless noted otherwise.

entries.name: Illumination
entries: Oil lamps provide dim light throughout the complex. Each lamp burns with a tall green flame as bright as torchlight.

entries.name: Portcullises
entries: Iron portcullises secure certain areas of the temple. The bars of a portcullis are 1 inch thick and spaced 4 inches apart. A portcullis can be raised or lowered using an iron lever nearby. If the lever can't be reached, the portcullis can be forced up or down by characters with a combined Strength of 30 or more, but doing so breaks the mechanisms that keep the portcullis from dropping. A {@spell knock} spell also raises a closed portcullis.

entries.name: Ramps
entries: In place of stairs, the temple has stone ramps, which snake-bodied yuan-ti find much easier to climb.

entries.name: Teleporters
entries: {@creature Ras Nsi|ToA} created five magical teleporters (in areas 8 through 12) that no one else is permitted to use. Each looks like a raised, faintly glowing stone disk with a serpentine glyph carved into the top of it. Each disk radiates an aura of conjuration magic under the scrutiny of a {@spell detect magic} spell.

If {@creature Ras Nsi|ToA} steps onto one of these disks, he can continue his movement from any other disk in the temple. A character with proficiency in the {@skill Arcana} skill can do the same thing by stepping onto the teleporter and succeeding on a DC 20 Intelligence ({@skill Arcana}) check. If the check succeeds but the character has no destination disk in mind, he or she appears atop a randomly determined one.

images.title: Map 4.1: Fane of the Night Serpent

entries.name: 1. Main Gate
entries: If characters approach this area from the north, read:
A wide passage slopes down to a set of bronze doors. Coiled serpents decorate the metal, with a sliding hatch at head height. Four-inch-wide holes pierce the base of each door.

When opened, the bronze doors slide into wall niches to either side of the tunnel. To pull the doors apart, the yuan-ti broodguards under Nahth's command tug on heavy chains on the south side of the gate. To bypass the doors without opening them, yuan-ti malisons transform into snakes and slither through the holes at the bottom of the doors.

A {@creature Yuan-ti Malison (Type 1)||type 1 yuan-ti malison} named Nahth (pronounced NAWTH) and four {@creature Yuan-ti Broodguard|VGM|yuan-ti broodguards} (see {@adventure appendix D|ToA|9}) defend the main gate. Strangers are denied entry unless they are accompanied by one or more yuan-ti.

Nahth is greedy. After allowing characters to pass through the gate, he demands a bribe in the form of food (preferably meat) or treasure (minimum 10 gp). If the characters refuse to pay up, Nahth picks a fight with them. Combat here draws reinforcements from {@area area 2|2b1|x}.

entries.name: Snake Pits
entries: Beyond the main gate are three pits covered with iron grates. When enemies attack, the broodguards remove the grated covers and form up in a defensive line on the south side of the open pits. Each pit is 5 feet across, 10 feet deep, and filled with a {@creature swarm of poisonous snakes}. The walls of each pit are too smooth to climb without the aid of gear or magic. A creature can skirt around the edge of a pit with a successful DC 10 Dexterity ({@skill Acrobatics}) check but falls if the check fails. A creature can also attempt to clear the pits with a standing jump or running jump (see the {@book Player's Handbook|PHB} for jumping rules), provided there are no broodguards lined up along the far side.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: Nahth has a crocodile skin pouch containing 28 gp and wears gold ceremonial bracers sculpted to resemble bats (150 gp for the pair).

entries.name: 2. Hall of War

entries: Four pillars carved with serpent reliefs support the 20-foot-high ceiling of this large room, in the middle of which is an 18-foot-high statue of a coiled cobra, facing north. Torches with green flames flicker on the walls, and the air reeks of dung. Two wagons are parked in one corner, and a triceratops is confined to a metal pen in another. To the west are a pair of dark alcoves, and to the south is a wide, pillared hall.

Yuan-ti troops muster in this hall before heading into the city. Unless they have been drawn elsewhere, a {@creature yuan-ti pureblood} named Soakosh (pronounced SOH-kawsh) and four {@creature Yuan-ti Broodguard|VGM|yuan-ti broodguards} (see {@adventure appendix D|ToA|9}) are stationed here. Two {@creature Basilisk||basilisks} chained to hooks in the western alcoves are trained not to look their yuan-ti masters in the eye. Chewed bits of stone (the remains of {@condition petrified} victims) litter the floor in the alcoves. The {@creature triceratops} confined to the metal pen in the northwest corner is docile until threatened. The yuan-ti use it to pull supply wagons.
Soakosh is fat and has a forked tongue. He's rarely seen without a bag of his favorite food at hand: candied grung eggs.

If the alarm is raised, Soakosh commands the broodguards to unchain the basilisks from their hooks and lead them into battle like war hounds. If the alarm has not been raised but combat ensues here, one broodguard runs to sound the gong in {@area area 9|2ca|x}.
If the triceratops is threatened with fire or injured by an attack, it smashes through the walls of its pen and heads toward {@area area 1|2ad|x}.

entries.name: Giant Cobra Statue
entries: The statue is not dangerous. A character can climb it with a successful DC 15 Strength ({@skill Athletics}) check.

entries.name: Wagons
entries: The supply wagons in the northeast corner are empty.

entries.name: 3. Hall of Serpents

entries: The walls of this pillared hall bear reliefs of a giant serpent and its yuan-ti worshipers doing terrible things.
The wall reliefs show the legend of Dendar the Night Serpent and the rise of {@creature Ras Nsi|ToA}. Characters who examine them see the following tableaus:

items: A giant serpent coils in the underworld, devouring the dreams of sleeping creatures.
Yuan-ti terrorize Chultans, feeding their nightmares to the great serpent.
A yuan-ti malison ({@creature Ras Nsi|ToA}) wielding a flaming sword and wearing a gold crown set with a black opal leads the snake people to a great door to the underworld.
The door to the underworld opens, releasing the serpent. It devours the sun and plunges the world into terror and darkness.

entries: A character who searches the reliefs and succeeds on a DC 15 Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) check discovers that the black opal in {@creature Ras Nsi|ToA}'s crown is a stone button. If the check succeeds by 5 or more, the character also sees tiny holes hidden among the scales of the Night Serpent carvings.

If a character presses the button in {@creature Ras Nsi|ToA}'s crown, the carvings of the Night Serpent expel a soporific gas that fills the hallway and lingers for 1 minute. Any creature that moves into the gas or starts its turn inside it must make a DC 13 Constitution saving throw. The gas has no effect on creatures that cannot be {@condition poisoned}, and creatures that fail the save fall {@condition unconscious} for 1 hour. Using cloth or wax, characters can plug the hundreds of holes and prevent the gas from flowing out.

entries.name: 4. Armory
entries: The armory door has an {@spell arcane lock} spell cast on it. Officially, only {@creature Ras Nsi|ToA}, {@creature Sekelok|ToA}, and {@creature Fenthaza|ToA} know the command phrase to bypass the spell ("white feather"). Speaking the command phrase while standing within 5 feet of the door suppresses its magic for 1 minute, during which time the door can be opened normally. The door can also be forced open with a {@spell knock} spell or a successful DC 25 Strength ({@skill Athletics}) check.
When the characters peer inside, read:

Gleaming scimitars, serpent helms, and suits of scale armor cram the racks of this vault. Large bones and horned skulls litter the floor, and a shield made from the shell of a tortoise hangs on the far wall.
A large skeletal serpent slithers out from behind the racks, raises its head, and says in Common, "They will tell us the passphrase! So Ukurlahmu has spoken."

A {@creature Bone Naga (Spirit)||bone naga} named Ukurlahmu (pronounced oo-ker-LAH-moo) has orders to protect the armory from thieves, but it struggles to remember faces. It only attacks creatures who fail to speak the correct passphrase. The current passphrase is "black mask." Characters are given three chances to utter the correct phrase before Ukurlahmu attacks. Before it attacks, the naga uses a bonus action to speak a magic command word that causes two {@creature Minotaur Skeleton||minotaur skeletons} to rise from the bones on the floor. The skeletons obey the naga.

Ukurlahmu speaks strangely. When it asks a question or makes a demand, it prefaces every sentence with "It will..." or "They will..." (for example, "It will tell us why it is here and what it wants"). When it makes a statement or answers a question, it always ends its sentences with "... so Ukurlahmu has spoken."

entries.name: Treasure
entries: The armory contains ten suits of scale armor, fifty scimitars, twenty longbows, twenty shortbows, and fifty quivers containing twenty arrows each. A {@spell detect magic} spell reveals an aura of transmutation magic around the shield hanging on the wall. The shield has a minor magical property: words spoken by the shield's bearer are amplified and sound ten times louder than normal.

The tortoise-shell shield belongs to {@creature Sekelok|ToA}, and only he is allowed to touch it. If a character removes the shield from the wall, Ukurlahmu coldly demands that it be returned it to its hook, attacking if this instruction is ignored.

entries.name: 5. Fenthaza's Quarters
entries: Two {@creature Yuan-ti Malison (Type 2)||type 2 yuan-ti malisons} stand guard in the corridor outside this room. Combat in the hallway alerts the yuan-ti broodguards in {@area area 6|2be|x}, which arrive in 1 round. The room can be described as follows:

A haze of incense lingers inside the chamber. Faded murals decorate the walls, and throw rugs and cushions lie scattered on the floor. An engraved chest rests in one corner next to a stone urn covered with snake carvings. A creature with the head and upper body of a dark-skinned woman and the lower body of a serpent coils in the middle of the room.

{@creature Fenthaza|ToA}, a {@creature yuan-ti nightmare speaker|VGM} (see {@adventure appendix D|ToA|9}), lairs here. If an alarm is raised, {@creature Fenthaza|ToA} relies on her guards to protect her while she releases the creature trapped in the stone urn (see below). {@creature Fenthaza|ToA} tries to incapacitate interlopers and confine them to {@area area 8|2c6|x}. A particularly irksome foe might be shackled to the altar in {@area area 6|2be|x}, where she can torture it at her leisure.

One of the more powerful figures in the temple, {@creature Fenthaza|ToA} ruled the yuan-ti after their abomination leader died, and she performed the ritual that transformed {@creature Ras Nsi|ToA} into a malison. Recently, her visions have led her to doubt {@creature Ras Nsi|ToA}'s capabilities. In turn, {@creature Ras Nsi|ToA} has started to cede power to his champion, {@creature Sekelok|ToA} ({@area area 12|2e1|x}).

entries.name: Stone Urn
entries: The stone urn stands 4 feet tall and weighs 250 pounds. Its stone lid weighs 25 pounds. Trapped within the urn is an {@creature air elemental} that obeys {@creature Fenthaza|ToA}. If the urn's lid is removed by someone other than {@creature Fenthaza|ToA}, the elemental flies out and attacks.
{@creature Fenthaza|ToA} uses the elemental to hunt down and slay escaped prisoners. Once it has completed its task, the elemental always returns to its mistress.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: {@creature Fenthaza|ToA} carries a ring of keys that unlock the manacles and shackles worn by the prisoners in {@area area 8|2c6|x}. She wears a holy symbol of Dendar the Night Serpent (25 gp) around her neck.

The chest is unlocked and contains 200 gp, a black leather quiver embroidered with a quartz-studded star map (75 gp), and a ceremonial dagger in a gold scabbard embossed with a scene of stampeding jungle animals (25 gp).

entries.name: 6. Sacrificial Chamber
entries: Unless they are lured to {@area area 5|2ba|x} by sounds of battle, four {@creature Yuan-ti Broodguard|VGM|yuan-ti broodguards} (see {@adventure appendix D|ToA|9}) stand guard in this chamber, one in each corner.

A bloodstained altar stands in the middle of this room. It has shackles bolted to its top and niches carved into its sides. Housed in each niche is a human skull. Grooves run down the altar to gutters on the floor, allowing spilled blood to drain into the walls. Clay urns overflow with wet bones and gore.

{@creature Fenthaza|ToA} routinely sacrifices prisoners on the altar. As they die, their blood drains into the pool in {@area area 9|2ca|x}. A captured character who insults or otherwise annoys {@creature Fenthaza|ToA} might end up here, shackled to the altar.

entries.name: Chanting Skulls
entries: The altar has six niches (one at each end and two on each long side). The human skull in each niche radiates an aura of abjuration magic under the scrutiny of a {@spell detect magic} spell. If combat ensues here, the skulls start to chant in Abyssal. The skulls stop chanting when they are removed from their niches or when combat ends. Each skull has AC 9, 1 hit point, and immunity to poison and psychic damage. As long as one or more skulls are chanting, all yuan-ti in the room gain the following benefits:

items: Resistance to bludgeoning, piercing, and slashing damage from nonmagical attacks
Advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects

entries.name: Portcullis
entries: A portcullis seals the entrance to {@area area 8|2c6|x}. A bronze lever is set into the wall south of the gate, out of sight of {@area area 8|2c6|x}. Lifting the lever raises the portcullis, and pulling the lever down causes the portcullis to drop.

entries.name: 7. Evil Oracle

entries: Steam rises from a stone basin filled with viscous black and purple liquid. Three serpentine creatures surround the pool. Each has the head and upper body of a dark-skinned woman and the lower body of a snake.

{@creature Yuan-ti Priest|ToA|Yuan-ti priests} use the pool to commune with Dendar the Night Serpent. Three priests named Arakiti, Kultha, and Nyss are here at all times. They are loyal to {@creature Fenthaza|ToA} and are {@creature Yuan-ti Malison (Type 3)||type 3 yuan-ti malisons}, with these changes:

items: Add the following to the list of spells that the yuan-ti can innately cast at will: {@spell eldritch blast} (2 beams; +5 to hit; {@dice 1d10 + 3} force damage per beam), {@spell minor illusion}, and {@spell poison spray}.
They don't carry longbows.

entries.name: Oracle Pool
entries: The sludge within the pool conducts the reveries of Dendar the Night Serpent. A creature that enters the sludge or starts its turn in the pool takes 5 ({@dice 1d10}) psychic damage.

Any creature that gazes into the pool for more than a few seconds receives a brief, nightmarish vision. In this vision, the creature is being swallowed whole by a giant snake. When the vision ends, the creature must make a DC 15 Wisdom saving throw. On a failed save, the creature takes 5 ({@dice 1d10}) psychic damage and is afflicted with a random form of long-term madness (see "{@book Madness|DMG|8|Madness}" in chapter 8 of the {@i Dungeon Master's Guide}).

entries.name: Prisoners of the Yuan-ti
entries: Yuan-ti captives not put to work as slaves are imprisoned in cells until they can be sacrificed to Dendar the Night Serpent. Ten sample prisoners are described below, and you can create others. All prisoners wear manacles on their wrists and ankles (see {@area area 8|2c6|x} for details). They've been stripped of their armor and weapons unless noted otherwise. All seek to escape the temple and make their way back to their homes or return to civilization.

items: Tahvo, a ten-year-old boy (LG male Chultan human noncombatant with AC 10 and 2 hit points), wears a flower garland and prays constantly to Tymora.

Sev, a {@creature yuan-ti pureblood} who looks human except for his forked tongue, is suffering the effects of blue mist fever (see "{@area Diseases|0a4|x}") and throws stones at illusory blue monkeys only he can see.

Oloma Authdamar (CG female Turami human {@creature scout}) is a former crew member of the Star Goddess (see {@area chapter 2|1aa|x}). She leapt from a porthole as the ship crashed, and the yuan-ti captured her in the jungle. Oloma carries a concealed dagger.
Pottery Shard, a {@creature tabaxi minstrel|ToA} (see {@adventure appendix D|ToA|9}), was kidnapped while traveling from Port Nyanzaru to Fort Beluarian.
Gorvax, a {@creature firenewt warrior|VGM} (see {@adventure appendix D|ToA|9}) is eager to escape and return to the Valley of Lost Honor.

A Harper named Lomar Dral (LG male Turami human {@creature mage} with no spell slots remaining). While searching for {@creature Artus Cimber|ToA} in Port Nyanzaru, he was drugged by the yuan-ti guide {@creature Salida|ToA} and woke up a prisoner in Omu.

Mung, a Batiri goblin, was caught by the yuan-ti while foraging in the jungle. He is malnourished and suffers from 3 levels of {@condition exhaustion} (see {@condition exhaustion||appendix A} of the Player's Handbook).

Kanush Natombe (N male Chultan human {@creature tribal warrior}) foolishly traveled to Omu to prove his worth to another man. Kanush is malnourished and suffers from 4 levels of {@condition exhaustion}.

Zilla Atazi (LE female Chultan human {@creature bandit}) was a pirate aboard the Dragonfang. Captain {@creature Elok Jaharwon|ToA} threw Zilla overboard for insubordination. The yuan-ti captured her after she washed ashore.

entries.name: 8. Prisoner Pits
entries: An iron portcullis seals this chamber. The lever to raise it is located in {@area area 6|2be|x}.
Characters captured by the yuan-ti are confined here. If this is how the characters first arrive, read:
The stench of sweat fills the humid air. You are chained to the wall of a dank, partially flooded pit. Other prisoners whimper nearby, lit by faint torchlight from the hole above.
If characters peer into this room through the portcullis, use this description instead:

Muffled sobs and moans rise from four pits with circular iron grates covering them. A chain hooked to each grate stretches over a pulley bolted to the ceiling and coils around an iron winch set into a nearby wall. Iron manacles dangle from hooks on the south wall. To the north, a faintly glowing stone disk covers the floor of an otherwise empty alcove, and carved into the top of the disk is a serpentine symbol.

The room contains four pits, each one a bell-shaped chamber 10 feet deep and 10 feet in diameter. The pits are flooded to a depth of 3 feet. Covering each pit is a 600-pound circular iron grate that requires one or more characters with a combined Strength score of at least 20 to lift. Alternatively, a character can use the iron winch near each pit to lift or lower its lid with a successful DC 12 Strength check. Climbing the slippery, sloped walls of a pit requires a DC 25 Strength ({@skill Athletics}) check.

New prisoners are slapped in chains and dropped into a random pit. The yuan-ti strip all prisoners of their belongings, which are kept in the storeroom ({@area area 13|2e7|x}) until they are properly inventoried. If the yuan-ti need to get a prisoner out of the pit, they disconnect a hook from the lid and use it to hoist the prisoner out by the manacles.

Each pit contains {@dice 1d3} prisoners, and the "{@adventure Prisoners of the Yuan-ti|ToA|4|Prisoners of the Yuan-ti}" sidebar describes several. If a player character dies, you could introduce a replacement character here as a prisoner hoping to be rescued.

Prisoners are forced to wear manacles on their wrists and shackles on their ankles. The manacles impose disadvantage on ability checks made to climb or swim. The shackles reduce a prisoner's walking speed by half and impose disadvantage on ability checks made to jump. {@creature Fenthaza|ToA} (see {@area area 5|2ba|x}) carries the keys for these bindings. See "{@book Adventuring Gear|PHB|5|Adventuring Gear}" in chapter 5 of the {@i Player's Handbook} for rules on breaking, escaping, and unlocking manacles (and shackles).

entries.name: Teleporter
entries: The engraved stone disk in the northern alcove is one of {@creature Ras Nsi|ToA}'s magic teleporters (see "{@area Teleporters|2ac|x}").

entries.name: 9. The Fane

entries: An underground cathedral opens before you. At one end, a sculptured balcony perches atop five rearing stone serpents. Blood dribbling from the serpents' jaws falls into a semicircular basin, and from there flows along a sloped trough into a wide stone bowl set into the floor. South of the bowl is a mezzanine, prominently situated atop which is a cauldron of steaming broth that exudes fleshy odors. To the west, a huge gong carved with snake patterns stands on a second balcony.

During rituals, the fane swells with yuan-ti, but the room is unguarded otherwise. When struck, the gong can be heard throughout the temple complex. One strike announces the start of a serpent ritual: when sounded, all the yuan-ti within the temple complex arrive here within half an hour. Two or more strikes in quick succession signal an alarm: when sounded, yuan-ti throughout the temple converge on this location as quickly as possible (see the Temple Roster table).

entries.name: Blood Pool
entries: Blood spilled in {@area area 6|2be|x} is channeled into this room, and the central pool contains {@dice 3d6} inches of viscid, days-old blood from previous sacrifices. The yuan-ti wallow in the blood from time to time, and slaves are sometimes brought here to be eaten alive by crazed revelers or transformed into yuan-ti (see "{@area Yuan-ti Rituals|2d0|x}" below).

entries.name: Cauldron
entries: A stew made from boiled flesh sloshes inside the cauldron, which is heated by a volcanic vent in the floor underneath it. Upturning the cauldron is an action that requires a successful DC 15 Strength check. When the cauldron is tipped, each creature on the floor within a 15-foot cone of the cauldron must make a DC 12 Dexterity saving throw, taking 4 ({@dice 1d8}) fire damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

entries.name: North Balcony and Teleporter
entries: {@creature Ras Nsi|ToA} and {@creature Fenthaza|ToA} use the north balcony to address underlings. To climb up, a character must succeed on a DC 13 Strength ({@skill Athletics}) check. The balustrades around the balcony provide half cover against ranged attacks originating from the room below.
Set into the back wall is an alcove with an engraved stone disk on the floor—one of {@creature Ras Nsi|ToA}'s magic teleporters (see "{@area Teleporters|2ac|x}").

entries.name: Portcullis
entries: A portcullis seals the entrance to {@area area 10|2d5|x}. A bronze lever is set into the wall north of the gate, out of sight of {@area area 10|2d5|x}. Lifting the lever raises the portcullis, and pulling the lever down causes the portcullis to drop.

entries.name: Yuan-ti Rituals
entries: Once every ten days, the yuan-ti gather in the fane for a depraved ritual. The ceremony takes place over the course of one night, with a skeleton crew guarding the rest of the temple complex during these periods.

During the ritual, mesmerizing incense is burned in the wall sconces. (See {@area area 13|2e7|x} for more information on the incense.) {@creature Fenthaza|ToA} preaches to the congregation from the north balcony. As the ceremony reaches fever pitch, she joins the revelers in the blood pool to feast on the slaves before slithering back to her quarters. On occasion, human slaves are transformed into yuan-ti purebloods or broodguards during these rituals. To undergo the change, slaves must bathe with snakes in the blood of sacrificial victims while under the influence of temple drugs. The transformation leaves each slave with {@dice 1d6} levels of {@condition exhaustion}. Once they've shed their old skin, those who survive the process are taken to their new home in the yuan-ti nests ({@area area 18|2f5|x}) to recuperate. Those who die are fed to the hydra in {@area area 21|2ff|x}.

{@creature Fenthaza|ToA} can arrange for captured human characters to be transformed into yuan-ti purebloods so they can roam freely within the temple complex and get closer to {@creature Ras Nsi|ToA}. The transformation can be undone only by a {@spell wish} spell or divine intervention. Characters who survive it gain a random form of indefinite madness (see "{@book Madness|DMG|8|Madness}" in chapter 8 of the {@i Dungeon Master's Guide}). A human that undergoes and survives the ritual retains its traits and gains the following yuan-ti racial traits.

entries.name: Darkvision
entries: You can see in dim light within 60 feet of you as if it were bright light, and in darkness as if it were dim light. You can't discern color in darkness, only shades of gray.

entries.name: Innate Spellcasting
entries: You know the {@spell poison spray} cantrip. You can cast {@spell animal friendship} an unlimited number of times with this trait, but you can target only snakes with it. Starting at 3rd level, you can also cast {@spell suggestion} with this trait. Once you cast it, you can't do so again until you finish a long rest. Charisma is your spellcasting ability for these spells.

entries.name: Magic Resistance
entries: You have advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

entries.name: Poison Immunity
entries: You are immune to poison damage and the {@condition poisoned} condition.

entries.name: 10. Harem
entries: An iron portcullis seals the entrance to this chamber. To raise it, a creature must lift a lever in {@area area 9|2ca|x}.

A fountain of cool water bubbles on the floor ahead. The scent of lilies fills the air, and silken drapes drift lazily in the heat. Archways open into shaded booths heaped with cushions and trays of sugared sweets. Lounging about are a dozen scantily clad humanoids with eyes like those of snakes and scaly patches on their arms, legs, necks, and backs. Watching over them are a pair of inhuman bipedal reptiles.

{@creature Ras Nsi|ToA}'s concubines live in luxury within these chambers. Eleven {@creature Yuan-ti Pureblood||yuan-ti purebloods} and a {@creature doppelganger} disguised as a pureblood comprise the harem. Two {@creature Yuan-ti Broodguard|VGM|yuan-ti broodguards} (see {@adventure appendix D|ToA|9}) watch over the harem at all hours.

{@creature Ras Nsi|ToA} used to spend much of his time here, sampling the harem's delights. Since the death curse took hold of him, he has cloistered himself elsewhere. The purebloods neither help nor hinder the characters, and they fear {@creature Ras Nsi|ToA} enough not to betray him willingly. Despite {@creature Ras Nsi|ToA}'s efforts to hide the effects of the death curse, the concubines know that he is sick and dying.

{@creature Ras Nsi|ToA}'s yuan-ti champion, {@creature Sekelok|ToA} ({@area area 11|2da|x}), is fascinated by the concubine Neema and courts disaster by visiting her in the dead of night. Neema browbeats the other concubines to cover up her affair.

entries.name: Doppelganger Spy
entries: The doppelganger infiltrated the temple by killing and assuming the form of a male yuan-ti pureblood named Ishmakahl (pronounced ISH-mah-kawl). It has been sent by Zagmira, a Red Wizard, to spy on {@creature Ras Nsi|ToA}. Unfortunately for its employers, the doppelganger has had little contact with {@creature Ras Nsi|ToA} since arriving at the fane; however, it has learned a few things by eavesdropping on {@creature Sekelok|ToA} and Neema's intimate conversations.

Ishmakahl appears as a handsome Chultan man with eyes like a snake's. If the characters make contact with the doppelganger on behalf of the Red Wizards, it offers to help them steal any puzzle cubes from {@creature Ras Nsi|ToA}'s lair ({@area area 12|2e1|x}). Ishmakahl knows the layout of the temple and knows there's a secret door somewhere in the throne room ({@area area 11|2da|x}) that leads to {@creature Ras Nsi|ToA}'s lair. The doppelganger also knows that {@creature Ras Nsi|ToA}'s lair can be reached via the fane's teleporters, though it doesn't know how to activate them. It advises the characters to break into the lair when {@creature Sekelok|ToA} next visits the harem.

Ishmakahl is secretly contemplating a defection to the yuan-ti. If its plan shows any signs of backfiring, the doppelganger reveals itself to {@creature Ras Nsi|ToA} or {@creature Sekelok|ToA}, and warns him about the intruders.

entries.name: Teleporter
entries: The eastern booth contains an alcove, set into the floor of which is a faintly glowing stone disk engraved with a serpentine symbol. This is one of {@creature Ras Nsi|ToA}'s magic teleporters (see "{@area Teleporters|2ac|x}").

entries.name: Treasure
entries: Characters who loot these chambers gain the following treasures: a white gold tiara made from two intertwined vipers with topaz eyes (750 gp), a jade trinket box shaped like a flytrap with curling golden leaves (250 gp), and two golden cobra candlesticks (75 gp each).

entries.name: 11. Throne Room

entries: Four pillars support the vaulted ceiling, and steps ascend to an iron throne carved in the likeness of a hydra. Painted on the wall behind it is a large blue triangle. To the south, an engraved stone disk is set into the floor of an alcove. A ten-foot-wide opening in the east wall leads to a flooded cave.
Circumstances determine this room's occupants:

items: During the day, {@b Ras Nsi} (see {@adventure appendix D|ToA|9}) "sits" in the throne while addressing two {@creature Yuan-ti Malison (Type 1)||type 1 yuan-ti malisons} who routinely advise him. Standing guard in the middle of the room is {@creature Ras Nsi|ToA}'s champion, {@creature Sekelok|ToA} (see below), and three {@creature Yuan-ti Broodguard|VGM|yuan-ti broodguards} (see {@adventure appendix D|ToA|9}). Hidden behind the throne are four {@creature Ghoul||ghouls} that obey {@creature Ras Nsi|ToA}'s commands. Each ghoul has a blue triangle tattooed on its forehead.

At night, {@creature Ras Nsi|ToA} retires to {@area area 12|2e1|x}, leaving the other yuan-ti (including {@creature Sekelok|ToA}) and the ghouls here. {@creature Sekelok|ToA} sometimes sneaks off to the harem ({@area area 10|2d5|x}).

If the gong in {@area area 9|2ca|x} is struck, {@creature Sekelok|ToA} and the other yuan-ti leave to investigate while the ghouls hide behind the throne and {@creature Ras Nsi|ToA} withdraws to {@area area 12|2e1|x}.

entries.name: Sekelok
entries: {@creature Sekelok|ToA} is a tall, muscular yuan-ti pureblood. He has the statistics of a {@creature champion|VGM} (see {@adventure appendix D|ToA|9}), with these changes:

items: {@creature Sekelok|ToA} is neutral evil.
He wears no armor, but his scales are as hard as steel (AC 18).
He is immune to poison damage and the {@condition poisoned} condition.
He has {@sense darkvision} out to a range of 60 feet.
He speaks Abyssal, Common, and Draconic.
He has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.
He has the Innate Spellcasting trait described below.

entries.name: Innate Spellcasting
entries: {@creature Sekelok|ToA}'s spellcasting ability is Charisma (spell save DC 13). He can innately cast the following spells, requiring no material components:

items: At will: {@spell animal friendship} (snakes only), {@spell poison spray}
3/day: {@spell suggestion}

entries: {@creature Sekelok|ToA} is {@creature Ras Nsi|ToA}'s trusted bodyguard and takes grim pleasure in slaughtering his master's enemies. {@creature Ras Nsi|ToA} delights in forcing those who offend him to duel {@creature Sekelok|ToA}, either to the first cut or to the death.

{@creature Sekelok|ToA} has a secret affair with Neema, one of {@creature Ras Nsi|ToA}'s concubines (see {@area area 10|2d5|x}). His motivations here are confused: while he remains staunchly loyal to {@creature Ras Nsi|ToA}, the subterfuge fuels his ego. If {@creature Ras Nsi|ToA} discovers the affair, he flays both parties alive for their betrayal and feeds them to his pet hydra (see {@area area 21|2ff|x}).

entries.name: Secret Door
entries: A secret door in the western corner of the north wall leads to {@creature Ras Nsi|ToA}'s lair ({@area area 12|2e1|x}). To locate the secret door, a character must succeed on a DC 16 Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) check while searching the walls. If the characters have been told about the secret door, they gain advantage on the skill check.

entries.name: Teleporter
entries: The engraved stone disk in the southern alcove is one of {@creature Ras Nsi|ToA}'s magic teleporters (see "{@area Teleporters|2ac|x}").

entries.name: 12. Ras Nsi's Lair

entries: Shadows dance over this opulent bedchamber. Cushions lie in one corner, and decorative shields line the walls. Treasures are heaped around the room: gold and silver coins; a gilded harp; a jeweled wine flask; pillows of silk; and fine clothes draped over wooden mannequins. To the east, an engraved stone disk is set into the floor of an alcove. To the west, a rectangular steel plate mounted on the wall is polished to a mirror-like sheen.

At night, {@creature Ras Nsi|ToA} (see {@adventure appendix D|ToA|9}) rests here, weakened by the death curse that is slowly consuming him. If enemies corner {@creature Ras Nsi|ToA}, shields leap from the walls to protect him (see "Flying Shields" below). During waking hours, {@creature Ras Nsi|ToA} returns here only if he's in danger.
If the characters defeat {@creature Ras Nsi|ToA} and question him, he reveals the following information to save his skin:

items: {@creature Ras Nsi|ToA} is slowly rotting to death. He doesn't know the cause of his affliction and has no way to cure it.
Before he dies, {@creature Ras Nsi|ToA} wants to bring forth Dendar the Night Serpent and destroy the world.

The yuan-ti believe there's a locked gate somewhere under the Peaks of Flame that prevents the Dendar from entering the world. {@creature Acererak|ToA} has promised to help {@creature Ras Nsi|ToA} unlock the gate and bring forth the Night Serpent. In return, {@creature Ras Nsi|ToA} defends the Tomb of the Nine Gods.
Nine stone puzzle cubes are needed to enter the Tomb of the Nine Gods. {@creature Ras Nsi|ToA} doesn't know how to use the cubes to unlock the tomb.
The tomb entrance is marked with an obelisk. ({@creature Ras Nsi|ToA} can provide directions and/or an escort.)
{@creature Acererak|ToA} slew the nine gods of Omu before enslaving the city's inhabitants, which he used to build his tomb.

entries.name: Flying Shields
entries: As a bonus action, {@creature Ras Nsi|ToA} can speak a command word ("Ssilum") that causes five shields to fly off the walls and levitate around him. While they're active, {@creature Ras Nsi|ToA} gains a +10 bonus to his AC. If an attack that would normally hit {@creature Ras Nsi|ToA} is blocked by the shields, one of the shields is struck and disabled as it falls to the floor, reducing {@creature Ras Nsi|ToA}'s bonus to AC by 2. When there are no more active shields, the effect ends, and {@creature Ras Nsi|ToA} can't use this power again until he finishes a long rest. A {@spell detect magic} or similar effect reveals an aura of transmutation magic around the shields. Only {@creature Ras Nsi|ToA} can activate the shields, and the effect is confined to this room.

entries.name: Teleporter
entries: The engraved stone disk in the eastern alcove is one of {@creature Ras Nsi|ToA}'s magic teleporters (see "{@area Teleporters|2ac|x}").

entries.name: Treasure
entries: {@creature Ras Nsi|ToA} wields a {@item flame tongue} longsword and carries a {@item Sending Stones||sending stone}. The companion stone is in {@creature Salida|ToA|Salida's} possession (see "{@area Finding a Guide|098|x}").

{@creature Ras Nsi|ToA}'s lair contains treasures from distant lands. The collection includes a Sembian wine flask (50 gp), a bejeweled Amnian doublet with matching money pouch (75 gp), a fine Cormyrean cloak (100 gp), a gilded Moonshae harp (250 gp), and three large cushions covered in Turami silk (25 gp each). Hidden under one of the cushions is {@creature Ras Nsi|ToA}'s leather-bound spellbook, which contains all the spells he has prepared (see {@adventure appendix D|ToA|9}). In addition, his hoard contains thirty 50 gp gemstones in a clay urn, 150 pp in an unlocked wooden chest, 350 gp and 900 sp scattered on the floor, and a froghemoth statuette made of painted wood with three amethyst gemstones for eyes (100 gp each).

entries.name: Puzzle Cubes
entries: If {@creature Ras Nsi|ToA} has taken one or more puzzle cubes from the shrines of Omu, they can be found among the items in his hoard.

entries.name: 13. Storeroom
entries: The southwest double door is locked. Using thieves' tools, a character can pick the lock with a successful DC 15 Dexterity check.
Stacks of sturdy wood crates, bundles of cloth, and clay amphorae litter the floor.

Supplies gathered from the world above are stored in this chamber. An awakened {@creature giant constrictor snake} named Azi Mas serves as custodian for the provisions. When fresh goods arrive, Azi Mas personally checks them and mentally catalogs them. The rest of the time, he remains coiled in the shadows. The snake is bored and enjoys chatting with yuan-ti visitors. Should other creatures enter from the southwest, Azi Mas ambushes them and tries to take a hostage. If outmatched, he whines and pleads for mercy.

Long ago, a jungle druid used an {@spell awaken} spell on Azi Mas, giving him an Intelligence of 10 and the ability to speak Common. After serving him for the duration of the enchantment, the serpent slithered off and found its way to Omu. Azi Mas has a good memory; he can remember names and faces and is quick to warn his masters if yuan-ti pass through whom he hasn't seen before.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: The storeroom contains fifty bolts of cloth; six crates of bronze bars; three barrels of salt and spices; and three chests containing rope, oil, lanterns, paper, and blankets. From the supplies, characters can assemble enough gear to make five explorer's packs.

entries.name: Mesmerizing Incense
entries: Also present is a sealed case containing ten blocks of temple incense. Lighting a block creates a hazy cloud that fills a 20-foot-diameter sphere and moves with the block. Any creature that starts its turn in the cloud and breathes the air must succeed on a DC 16 Constitution saving throw or fall into a dreamlike stupor laced with nightmarish visions. Though it remains awake, the creature is {@condition poisoned}. Even yuan-ti are vulnerable to this effect, which lasts for 1 hour after a creature leaves the cloud, or until it receives a {@spell lesser restoration} spell or similar magic.

entries.name: 14. Venom Distillery
entries: The south door is locked, and the lock contains a cleverly hidden poison needle trap. To pick the lock, a character with thieves' tools must succeed on a DC 15 Dexterity check. Finding the trap requires a successful DC 20 Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) check; once found, it can be disabled with a successful DC 12 Dexterity check. A character who tries to pick the lock without first disabling the trap must make a DC 16 Dexterity saving throw. On a failed save, the character is pricked by the needle, takes 5 ({@dice 1d10}) poison damage, and is {@condition blinded}. The blindness is permanent but can be cured with a {@spell lesser restoration} spell or similar magic.

The air in here is moist and sticky. Natural light spills from cracks in the ceiling, and mud coats the floor. Stone workbenches are laden with clay bottles of various shapes and sizes. Toadstools, snakeroot, and belladonna plants grow among the clutter, fed by water seeping from above. Standing near the plants is a hairless man with scaly skin and a bronze syringe. Lurking in the shadows around him are five slouching humans that reek of decay.

Yuan-ti use this chamber to extract venom from snakes. Xopal (pronounced zoh-PAUL), a {@creature yuan-ti pureblood}, bottles and blends the venom to create deadly new strains. Five human {@creature Zombie||zombies} serve Xopal as laborers.

Xopal carries a bronze syringe containing three doses of a poison cocktail. As an action, he can make a melee weapon attack with the syringe (+3 to hit), which deals 1 piercing damage and injects one dose of poison on a hit. Any creature injected with a dose of poison must make a DC 14 Constitution saving throw, taking 10 ({@dice 3d6}) poison damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one. In addition, the creature is {@condition poisoned} for 1 hour whether or not its save succeeds.

Xopal believes it's his destiny to transform into a much more powerful form of yuan-ti—a metamorphosis that will occur when he develops a poison so virulent that even innate immunity to poison can't withstand it. Xopal uses the zombies as test subjects; once he's overcome their immunity, he plans to conduct further tests on live yuan-ti.

entries.name: Bottled Poisons
entries: The presence of so many poisons makes combat in this room hazardous. If a workbench is exposed to explosive force, such as that generated by a {@spell thunderwave} or {@spell fireball} spell, the bottles smash and create a 15-foot-radius sphere of poisonous vapors that lasts for 1 minute. Any creature that enters the area for the first time on a turn or starts its turn within the sphere must make a DC 15 Constitution saving throw, taking 18 ({@dice 4d8}) poison damage on a failed save. Creatures are affected even if they hold their breath or don't need to breathe.

Among the poisons is a stoppered bronze jug used for fermenting jungle roots into soporific gas. Removing the stopper releases the gas, which fills a 15-foot-radius sphere centered on the jug. See {@area area 3|2b5|x} for the effect of the soporific gas.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: Xopal carries a brass key that unlocks the south door.

Characters who search through the poisons can loot twenty doses of serpent venom, five doses of essence of ether, and five doses of torpor (see "{@book Poisons|DMG|8|Poisons}" in chapter 8 of the {@i Dungeon Master's Guide}).

entries.name: 15. Snake Pit

entries: A rickety wooden walkway threads around the walls of a deep pit. Foul odors waft up from below. Somewhere in the gloom beneath you, thousands of snakes writhe.

Despite appearances, the rickety wooden walkway is safe. The yuan-ti sometimes hurl disobedient slaves into the pit to be devoured by the serpents. The pit is 50 feet deep and filled with poisonous snakes. When a creature falls or sets foot in the pit, a {@creature swarm of poisonous snakes} forms around it and attacks. A virtually inexhaustible number of swarms can be created in this fashion. A swarm that has nothing to attack ceases to exist as its constituents slither apart.
To climb the wet cavern walls, a character must succeed on a DC 15 Strength ({@skill Athletics}) check.

entries.name: 16. Blood Baths

entries: The iron stench of blood floods this chamber. Along one wall, a row of gore-filled pools sink into the floor. Blood trails and bloody footprints run between the pools.

When they awake each day, the yuan-ti ritually bathe in the blood of sacrifices. The blood is contained within these stone baths and heated by thermal vents underneath each pool. When the characters enter, four {@creature Yuan-ti Pureblood||yuan-ti purebloods} and two {@creature Yuan-ti Malison (Type 2)||type 2 yuan-ti malisons} bathe in the warm pools. Five slaves in loincloths (male and female Chultan human {@creature Commoner||commoners} of various alignments) tend to their every need. Give names to slaves as needed (see the "{@area Chultan Names|020|x}" sidebar in the book's introduction).

The blood-drenched yuan-ti keep their weapons at the back of each alcove. If they hear the gong alarm sound, the yuan-ti command their slaves to remain here while they arm themselves and head quickly to {@area area 9|2ca|x}. If combat breaks out here, reinforcements from {@area area 17|2f3|x} arrive in {@dice 1d3} rounds.

entries.name: 17. Sauna

entries: Heat rises from an enormous oval stone set into the floor of this chamber. Discarded skins are heaped around it, and shelves underneath it are lined with jars. A snake-headed yuan-ti sheds his skin while two strong, bare-chested human men with spears look on.
The oval stone is 8 feet tall and made of porous rock. Situated atop a volcanic vent, it transfers heat evenly throughout the room. The yuan-ti come here to shed their skins and polish their scales.

Thirty jars line the shelves underneath the oval stone, and each one contains a scented ointment that yuan-ti use to keep their skin supple and to ease the shedding of their skin. The ointment is not valuable.

Unless they have been fought and defeated elsewhere, two enslaved men (NE male Chultan human {@creature Gladiator||gladiators}) watch Yahru (pronounced YAH-roo), a {@creature Yuan-ti Malison (Type 1)||type 1 yuan-ti malison}, as he sheds his skin (a process that can take up to an hour). Yahru is {@creature Ras Nsi|ToA}'s spymaster, and he doesn't like to be disturbed. Characters passing themselves off as yuan-ti purebloods are instructed to leave the room at once. Enslaved characters are ordered to smear ointment on Yahru's skin to expedite the skin-shedding process.

Yahru abhors physical combat, and he values his bodyguards too much to risk their lives in a pointless battle. Unless the characters provoke a fight, he tries to find out more about them and learn any secrets they might possess, while providing as little information as possible. If Yahru obtains information that would clearly benefit {@creature Ras Nsi|ToA} or {@creature Fenthaza|ToA}, he chooses which superior to bequeath it to. Yahru enjoys playing them off against each other.

If his bodyguards are defeated and he is facing death, Yahru offers small bits of information for the promise of freedom. In addition to the layout and defenses of the temple, Yahru knows the following:

items: {@creature Ras Nsi|ToA} commands the yuan-ti of Omu, but his command is tenuous. The high priest, {@creature Fenthaza|ToA}, is {@creature Ras Nsi|ToA}'s chief rival.
{@creature Ras Nsi|ToA} is slowly being eaten away by a magical disease for which there is no known cure.

{@creature Ras Nsi|ToA} has made a pact with a powerful lich named {@creature Acererak|ToA}, who conquered Omu long ago and built a tomb beneath the city. The tomb's entrance is marked with an obelisk. (Yahru can provide directions.)
{@creature Acererak|ToA} slew the nine gods of Omu before enslaving the city's human and minotaur inhabitants, which he used to build his tomb.

entries.name: 18. Yuan-ti Nests

entries: These dank catacombs have been converted into sleeping quarters. The walls are lined with alcoves that now serve as nests for yuan-ti.

When the characters arrive, twelve of the eighteen alcoves are occupied by six {@creature Yuan-ti Malison (Type 1)||yuan-ti malisons} (two each of types 1, 2, and 3) and six {@creature Yuan-ti Pureblood||yuan-ti purebloods}. The remaining six alcoves are currently not in use. Passing through the area without being spotted is impossible unless the characters use magic to hide themselves.
If the gong in {@area area 9|2ca|x} is struck, all the yuan-ti in this room gather their weapons and investigate.

entries.name: 19. Slave Grotto

entries: A campfire casts warm light over this cavern. Heaps of dead grass and palm fronds are scattered about, and the muddy floor is pitted with footprints.

When they're not working, {@dice 2d10} slaves ({@creature Commoner||commoners} of various races, alignments, and genders) dwell here. For slave names, see the "{@area Chultan Names|020|x}" sidebar in the book's introduction. Three {@creature Yuan-ti Broodguard|VGM|yuan-ti broodguards} (see {@adventure appendix D|ToA|9}) guard the slaves for Slavemaster Issar, a {@creature Yuan-ti Malison (Type 3)||type 3 yuan-ti malison} wearing a red cloth headdress. Issar is more interested in gazing at his own reflection in a hand mirror than putting the slaves to work.

Issar is too stately to speak to the "meat" under his command. Instead, he's chosen a Chultan slave boy named Khoti to translate his subtle, unspoken gestures. A twitch of the tail could be interpreted as an order to fetch water, or the flick of the tongue an approval. In truth, Khoti makes up most of what he sees. Issar couldn't care less either way, as long as the correct amount of deference is shown. If strangers appear before Issar, Khoti questions them on his master's behalf.

entries.name: Slaves
entries: Under Issar's supervision, the slaves are supposed to be widening these caverns to create new sleeping quarters for the yuan-ti. However, progress has been slow. The slaves wore down or broke most of their tools, and Issar is waiting for the delivery of new tools.

The slaves are physically healthy, but their wills have been broken by mental trauma and tranquilizing drugs. Their emotions surface only during rest, when the dreams of the Night Serpent wrench them screaming from their troubled sleep.

The slaves are not chained. Presented with an opportunity to escape, most become {@condition paralyzed} with indecision. Breaking their fugue requires strong words and a successful DC 17 Charisma ({@skill Persuasion} or {@skill Intimidation}) check. Armed slaves who come to their senses try to slaughter as many yuan-ti as they can. They know the temple's defenses and general layout, except with regard to areas 11 and 12 (which they've never seen).

entries.name: Treasure
entries: Issar carries an iron key that unlocks the double door to {@area area 13|2e7|x}. His red cloth headdress is sewn with malachite gemstones (250 gp), and he preens in a golden hand mirror (75 gp).

entries.name: 20. Underground River

entries: An underground river opens before you. Stalactites hang low over its surface, and dripping water echoes in the dark.

The river links various sections of the complex. The water varies between 5 and 30 feet deep, and the current isn't strong enough to present a hazard to swimmers. To the north and south, the river descends into submerged tunnels that spread for miles under the jungle.

entries.name: Rowboats
entries: When the characters arrive, a pair of rowboats are pulled up on the shore near the tunnel to {@area area 23|303|x} (see {@table Owning a Ship; Airborne and Waterborne Vehicles||chapter 5} of the{@i Dungeon Master's Guide} for more information on rowboats). A cowbell dangles from a hook at the prow of each boat. Ringing either bell summons the hydra in {@area area 21|2ff|x}, which arrives in {@dice 1d6} rounds.

entries.name: Yuan-ti Broodguards
entries: Guarding the rowboats and watching the secret entrance ({@area area 23|303|x}) are four {@creature Yuan-ti Broodguard|VGM|yuan-ti broodguards} (see {@adventure appendix D|ToA|9}). If they detect intruders not disguised as yuan-ti, one broodguard runs to warn the yuan-ti stationed in {@area area 19|2f7|x} while the others attempt to repel the interlopers.

The broodguards stop and question characters disguised as yuan-ti purebloods. To bluff their way past the guards, the characters must succeed on a group DC 10 Charisma ({@skill Deception}) check. If the group check succeeds, the broodguards wave them inside without checking their story. If the group check fails, the broodguards march them to meet Slavemaster Issar in {@area area 19|2f7|x}.

entries.name: 21. Hydra's Lair

entries: An underground river widens to form a flooded grotto. To the west, a pebble-strewn bank rises to a door recessed in the cavern wall. Near the middle of the lake, bones cling like a tide mark to a rocky pillar.

A {@creature hydra} lurks underwater in this vicinity. {@creature Ras Nsi|ToA} treats the monster as his beloved pet and regularly feeds it slaves, prisoners, and subordinates who've defied him. The hydra's victims are bound and ferried on rowboats over the deepest part of the river. To call the monster, their captors sound the rowboat bell and hurl the hogtied victim (or victims) into the water.

While it remains fed, the hydra avoids any boats that ply back and forth. When a rowboat bell is sounded, the hydra surfaces within {@dice 1d6} rounds. If it's not fed immediately, it attacks the boat. The hydra attacks any boats that venture north of {@area area 18|2f5|x}. Swimmers are also fair game.

entries.name: 22. Fungi Cavern

entries: The passage widens into a cavern filled with fungi. Toadstools, puffballs, and other tuberous growths cover the walls and floor. Against the far wall, a malformed skeleton lies buried under a patch of buttery mold. A brass key hangs around its neck.
A patch of green slime (see {@hazard green slime||chapter 5} of the {@i Dungeon Master's Guide}) clings to the ceiling above the entrance and drops on the first creature that passes underneath.
A patch of yellow mold (see {@hazard yellow mold||chapter 5} of the {@i Dungeon Master's Guide}) covers the skeletal corpse. If a creature touches the mold, it ejects a cloud of deadly spores.

The corpse belongs to Kukuga, a yuan-ti pureblood who secretly worshiped Zuggtmoy (the demon queen of fungi). Kukuga concocted a fungal brew that would transform his body into a form closer to that of his demonic mistress. Instead, it led to his sudden and horrific death. Xopal ({@area area 14|2eb|x}) occasionally ventures into the cavern to harvest poisonous toadstools from his corpse.

To remove the brass key without disturbing the mold, a character must succeed on a DC 12 Dexterity ({@skill Sleight of Hand}) check. The key unlocks the door to the venom distillery ({@area area 14|2eb|x}).

entries.name: 23. Secret Entrance
entries: If characters enter this tunnel from the surface, read:
The passage winds into the bowels of the earth. The air is wet and sticky, and the walls are slick with moisture. Harmless centipedes crawl across the floor as you descend.
The tunnel is roughly 100 feet long. Characters who climb the tunnel toward the surface emerge amid the ruins of Omu's royal palace (see {@area chapter 3|292|x}, area 20B).

data.name: Chapter 5: Tomb of the Nine Gods
entries: {@creature Acererak|ToA} built the Tomb of the Nine Gods not only to house the remains of Omu's trickster gods, but also to slay interlopers. However, few today even know the tomb exists, and thus it remains an enigma. Rare are the tavern tales that lure adventurers to its gates, and its horrors remain undocumented in the libraries of Candlekeep. The reason for this is simple: not one person who has entered the tomb has lived to tell the tale.

entries.name: History of the Tomb
entries: As the characters plumb the depths of the Tomb of the Nine Gods, they'll learn snippets of its grisly past.

entries.name: Rise of the Tomb
entries: After {@creature Acererak|ToA} murdered Omu's gods, he enslaved the Omuans and forced them to carve a grand tomb under one of the cliffs surrounding the city. The archlich devised brutal trials for each burial chamber, and sprinkled riddles and illusions throughout to deceive intruders. When the building work was done, he fed his slaves into the death trap to test its efficacy. The archlich turned some of his victims into undead and flesh golems, then locked them inside the tomb to serve as guardians. {@creature Acererak|ToA} then resumed his wanderings.

In {@creature Acererak|ToA}'s absence, the tomb snared adventurers from faraway lands and harvested their souls to feed the archlich's phylactery, which remained hidden on another plane. Every few decades, {@creature Acererak|ToA} returned to tinker with his dungeon's traps, add treasure to its vaults, and reap a bounty of hoarded souls. His planar wanderings have influenced the tomb's mishmash of architectural styles, and have populated it with strange and deadly monsters.

entries.name: Nourishing the Atropal
entries: On one of his journeys through the cosmos, {@creature Acererak|ToA} stumbled upon an atropal (see {@adventure appendix D|ToA|9}). He brought it to Toril, ensconced it in the cradle of his tomb, and began feeding it necromantic energy, hoping to transform it into a deity: one able to claim dominion over death. Unleashed on Toril, the newborn death god would glut itself on life until none but the dead walked the world.

To nurture the atropal, {@creature Acererak|ToA} needed an untold number of souls. The archlich made a bargain with the Sewn Sisters, a coven of night hags feared throughout the Lower Planes. Seduced by the prospect of a near-endless supply of souls, the hags joined {@creature Acererak|ToA} in his tomb. With their assistance, the archlich crafted the Soulmonger—a necromantic device that could reap the souls of the dying from across Toril and feed them to the atropal. Leaving the Sewn Sisters behind as nursemaids, {@creature Acererak|ToA} abandoned his tomb to watch the rise of the death god from afar.

entries.name: Exploring the Tomb
entries: To survive the tomb's horrors, the player characters must call on every ounce of their cunning and willpower.

entries.name: General Features
entries: The following features are common throughout the tomb. Some levels of the tomb have additional features that are described at the beginning of their respective sections.

entries.name: Ceilings
entries: Unless specified otherwise, ceilings in the tomb are 8 feet high in corridors and 12 feet high in rooms.

entries.name: Crawlways
entries: Certain areas of the tomb are accessible only by way of narrow tunnels. These crawlways are 3 feet high and 2 feet wide.

entries.name: Lighting
entries: All areas of the tomb are unlit unless noted otherwise.

entries.name: Secret Doors
entries: Most secret doors within the tomb slide open on stone runners. The handles that unlock them are hidden within the features of relief carvings along the walls, including inside the jaws of many graven skulls.

A secret door can be spotted by any character within 5 feet of it who has a passive Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) score of 20 or higher, or with a search and a successful DC 20 Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) check.

entries.name: Staircases
entries: Stairs in the tomb are carved out of the living rock, and each step is topped with a single slab of cut stone. The skulls and bones of dead Omuans fill niches along the walls of each staircase. Staircases run 25 feet between each level of the tomb.

entries.name: Tracks
entries: Explorers have broken into the tomb recently, and {@creature Withers|ToA} and his tomb dwarves make frequent patrols. Their trails crisscross back and forth, making other creatures in the tomb difficult to track. The freshest tracks belong to the {@creature Skeleton Key|ToA|skeleton keys} (see "Tomb Inhabitants" below). Any character who tries to follow a {@creature skeleton key|ToA}'s trail can do so with a successful DC 12 Wisdom ({@skill Survival}) check, finding the way to the nearest unexplored location marked with a skull symbol on the dungeon map.

entries.name: Tomb Inhabitants
entries: A grim pageant of monstrous residents lurks in the tomb, waiting to greet visitors.

entries.name: Withers and the Tomb Dwarves
entries: {@creature Withers|ToA}, {@creature Acererak|ToA}'s undead custodian, oversees the undead maintenance crew that keeps the tomb's traps in working order. To assemble that team, {@creature Acererak|ToA} abducted dwarf miners and transformed them into wights to exploit their expertise at underground construction. {@creature Withers|ToA} acts as supervisor for the dwarves and serves as {@creature Acererak|ToA}'s adjunct when the archlich visits the tomb. Using his scrying pool at {@area area 25|39f|x}, {@creature Withers|ToA} can command Omu's gargoyles and speak to agents on the surface world.

{@creature Withers|ToA} and his crew use the staircase at {@area area 26|3a3|x} to roam unseen through the tomb's many levels. When their work is done, they retreat to their secret headquarters on level 2 of the tomb ({@area areas 27|3a5|x} and {@area 28|3aa|x}). {@creature Withers|ToA} avoids contact with the characters when possible, confident that {@creature Acererak|ToA}'s traps will defeat them.

entries.name: Legendary Monsters
entries: Two legendary monsters dwell in {@creature Acererak|ToA}'s tomb: a beholder guarding a treasure vault ({@area area 44|414|x}) and an aboleth lurking in an underground lake ({@area area 65|4b1|x}). These creatures can't use lair actions within the tomb, and the regional effects of each creature's lair are localized to the levels where they dwell.

Despite being the dungeon's creator, {@creature Acererak|ToA} doesn't count the Tomb of the Nine Gods as his lair. Consequently, no lair actions or regional effects are ascribed to the archlich in this adventure.

entries.name: Skeleton Keys
entries: To unlock the final gate to the Soulmonger, the adventurers must acquire five skeleton keys—each the carved skull of an animated human skeleton that roams the tomb. The characters can capture and control these skeletons, or can simply snap a skull off its spine.
A {@creature skeleton key|ToA} has the statistics of a {@creature skeleton}, with these changes:

items: The {@creature skeleton key|ToA} is unaligned.
It has a climbing speed of 30 feet and can climb difficult surfaces, including upside down on ceilings, without needing to make an ability check.
It wields a pair of daggers and can make two melee weapon attacks (+4 to hit) as an action. Each dagger attack deals 4 ({@dice 1d4 + 2}) piercing damage on a hit.
When reduced to 0 hit points, a {@creature skeleton key|ToA} falls apart, though its skull and bones remain intact.
A {@creature skeleton key|ToA} does not trigger any trap placed in a room or on a door of the tomb.

entries: Each {@creature skeleton key|ToA} has a skull that extends into a carved key-like shape. These shapes match the keyholes of the skeleton gate in the lair of the Sewn Sisters ({@area area 71|4d8|x}). The Skeleton Keys table summarizes the location and shape of each key.

entries.name: Finding a Skeleton Key
entries: Each of the first five levels of the tomb has its own {@creature skeleton key|ToA}. A {@creature skeleton key|ToA} can be encountered in any of the locations marked with a skull symbol on the level map. You choose a {@creature skeleton key|ToA}'s location. You can also change your mind and relocate the {@creature skeleton key|ToA} to make it easier or harder to find.

Apart from unlocking the skeleton gate in {@area area 71|4d8|x}, the skeleton keys perform no function. When the characters enter an area containing a {@creature skeleton key|ToA}, it might be standing in the middle of the room, standing in a corner, walking across the ceiling, or clinging to a wall. A {@creature skeleton key|ToA}'s primary goal is to avoid capture or destruction, so it flees if it can.

entries.name: The Sewn Sisters
entries: In the lowest level of the tomb, a coven of night hags nurses the atropal to its apotheosis. See {@area area 71|4d8|x} and "The Sewn Sisters" sidebar near that section for more information on the hags.

entries.name: Tomb Guardians
entries: Adventurers who have perished inside the tomb are stitched together by tomb dwarves and bolted into suits of armor. Once complete, these shambling golems are released into the tomb to hunt intruders.

A {@creature tomb guardian|ToA} is a {@creature flesh golem} clad in plate armor, giving it AC 17. One or two tomb guardians should appear whenever you feel the need for combat. As the characters delve deeper into the tomb, they should come to know these monsters well.

entries.name: Trickster God Spirits
entries: The spirits of the nine trickster gods of Omu haunt the tomb. Although they cannot escape it, these spirits can inhabit adventurers within the tomb (see "{@area Spirits of the Nine Trickster Gods|321|x}").

entries.name: Fabled Treasures
entries: Among the many treasures hidden in the tomb are four fabled art objects that hold special value. {@creature Acererak|ToA} uses them to lure adventurers to the tomb.
Any character with proficiency in the {@skill History} skill who lays eyes on one of these treasures can recall its lore with a successful DC 20 Intelligence ({@skill History}) check.

entries.name: Black Opal Crown
entries: The Black Opal Crown was once worn by the archmage Sadamor of Netheril. Legend speaks of how Sadamor saw the depths of humanity's evil reflected in the opal of his crown. Heartbroken, he created a doomsday device—a {@item sphere of annihilation}—to swallow the world but was consumed by his own creation.

The yuan-ti nightmare speaker {@creature Fenthaza|ToA} (see {@area chapter 4|2a1|x}) believes that the Black Opal Crown can awaken Dendar the Night Serpent. If the characters find the crown, {@creature Fenthaza|ToA} tries to kill them before they escape Chult with it. The crown rests in the maze of death ({@area area 49|442|x}).

entries.name: Eye of Zaltec
entries: For centuries, this fist-sized ruby surmounted the Great Pyramid in Nexal, capital city of the Maztican Empire. The gem is a relic of the cult of Zaltec, and its dagger-like point was plunged into the hearts of countless sacrifices.

An adventuring band known as the Company of the Yellow Banner entered Omu to find the Eye of Zaltec and was never seen again. The Eye of Zaltec is guarded by a stone juggernaut ({@area area 62|49f|x}).

entries.name: Navel of the Moon
entries: Said to be carved from a chunk of the moon, this polished egg-shaped stone was given as a gift by the ruling syl-pasha of Calimport to his sailor daughter. It is said that anyone who holds the stone can always find the way home to his or her loved ones.

The tabaxi hunter {@creature Bag of Nails|ToA} (see {@area chapter 3|22e|x}) came to Omu in search of the Navel of the Moon but failed to find it. The Navel of the Moon is set into the pendulum of a grandfather clock inside a secret room ({@area area 56|478|x}).

entries.name: Skull Chalice of Ch'gakare
entries: This jeweled goblet was crafted from the skull of a long-dead Omuan king and served as a symbol of office for the royal line of Omu. The legendary Chultan hero Ch'gakare (pronounced chuh-GAH-kah-ree) is said to have beheaded the king after escaping the Nine Hells on the back of a mastodon.

Princess Mwaxanaré (see "{@area Kir Sabal|13f|x}," and {@adventure appendix D|ToA|9}) is keen to recover the Skull Chalice of Ch'gakare as part of her bid to reclaim the throne of Omu. To obtain it, characters must first survive the perils of the hall of the golden mastodon ({@area area 67|4bd|x}).

entries.name: Spell Restrictions
entries: Many spells have altered effects when cast in the Tomb of the Nine Gods, including spells cast from magic items or artifacts, and class abilities that duplicate the effects of spells. {@creature Acererak|ToA}'s magic and the magic of the {@item amulet of the black skull|ToA} (see {@adventure appendix C|ToA|8}) are unaffected.

Spells that would normally allow creatures to transport into and out of the tomb either fail or deposit their recipients in {@area area 57|47d|x}. Spells that normally allow one to pass through stone fail, and divination spells cast within the tomb provide false readings. Spells designed to communicate over long distances are similarly foiled. These alterations are summarized in the Modified Spells table. Spells not included in the table might suffer similar alterations, at your discretion.

Magic that summons creatures or objects from other planes functions normally, as does magic that involves the creation of an extradimensional space. Any spells cast within an extradimensional space (such as that created by {@spell rope trick}) are subject to the same restrictions as magic cast in the tomb.

entries.caption: Modified Spells
rows: This spell does not prevent the spirits of trickster gods from inhabiting hosts. The spell also has no effect on the Soulmonger.
Any creature that tries to enter or leave the tomb using this spell appears in {@area area 57|47d|x}.
This spell fails if cast in the tomb or if its intended destination is inside the tomb.
This spell returns false readings if cast in the tomb.
Any creature banished by this spell appears in {@area area 57|47d|x}.
This spell fails if the sensor is meant to appear inside the tomb.
This spell returns no answer if cast in the tomb.
The caster enters the Border Ethereal but can't move through surfaces or doors in the tomb. Ethereal characters might encounter one or more of the Sewn Sisters.
This spell fails if cast in the tomb.
Any creature in the tomb that steps through the gate created by this spell appears in {@area area 57|47d|x}.
This spell does not allow passage through surfaces or doors in the tomb.
This spell has no effect on surfaces, doors, sarcophagi, stone blocks, or statues in the tomb.
This spell can't be used to escape the tomb.

entries.name: Replacing Dead Characters
entries: If a character dies in the Tomb of the Nine Gods and you need a hook to introduce a new party member, choose from the suggestions below or work with the character's player to devise something appropriate:

items: The replacement character broke into the tomb centuries ago but was imprisoned inside a magical carving. When one of the other characters accidentally leans against this carving, the replacement character is released from captivity.
